awd_titl_txt: Probing the Roles of the Surface versus the Bulk in Uptake of Gases Into Atmospherically Relevant Particles
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project involves an investigation into the role of the atmospheric particle surface versus the particle bulk composition in determining the uptake of organic gases and water into the particle.  This information is critical for the development of models to accurately predict the impacts of airborne particles on air quality, visibility and climate.

The specific objectives of this research are to: (1) examine the surface and bulk composition of a series of model solid organic particles both before and after heterogeneous oxidation using cutting edge mass spectrometry techniques implemented recently in this laboratory; (2) probe differences in surface vs bulk composition when oxidation of the organic is initiated from the gas phase ("outside in"), or from in-situ photochemistry induced by nitrate or nitrite ion photolysis ("inside out"); and (3) measure uptake of a range of organics as well as water into the above particles, before and after oxidation, in order to establish molecular relationships between gas-particle interactions and surface and bulk composition, and the impacts on particle growth and hygroscopicity. A series of laboratory experiments will be conducted to examine the uptake of a range of organic vapors onto model particles before and after oxidation.  The data generated by this effort will provide critical insights to improve predictions of particle impacts on climate, air quality, and human health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Atmospheric particles are a major air quality concern as their inhalation results in adverse health effects and increased mortality. Particles also scatter sunlight to impact visibility and become seeds for water condensation and cloud droplet formation. Both direct scattering from particles and scattering from clouds impact earth's radiative balance and hence climate. Characterization of particle formation, growth, composition, and interaction with water vapor are therefore needed from both air quality and climate standpoints.

The composition of airborne particles is complex and can depend on their sources. A large fraction of atmospheric particles is quite viscous and considered semisolids or solids. Their phase affects internal mixing timeframes relative to their atmospheric lifetimes. The surface composition of such particles can change over their lifetime while their bulk may remain protected from further chemistry. Moreover, their surface composition will determine the nature of their interactions with gases, oxidants, and water. Most particle composition techniques provide average composition which is biased toward the large number of molecules making up their core relative to the far fewer molecules in the surface layers.

Characterization of surface-sensitive mass spectrometry (MS) methods was the focus of this research. Matrix Assisted Ionization in Vacuum (MAIV) was first developed and applied by others to large biomolecules on substrates approximately ten years ago. We applied MAIV directly to submicron organic particles and found that its ionization mechanism is controlled by sublimation as they enter the MS inlet. Particles generated by atomization contain multiple charges that exhibit repulsion as they shrink, leading to ion ejection. Little energy is applied relative to existing ionization methods, thus MAIV better preserves compounds during detection. The most efficient matrix was glutaric acid, a five-carbon dicarboxylic acid, which efficiently retains multiple charges, but MAIV also occurs for three- to six-carbon dicarboxylic acids.

Surface-sensitivity of MAIV was shown by coating particles with known compounds up to 15 nm thick. Thick coatings led to MS signals of the coating compounds with no observation of the core. Thin coatings less than 5 nm yielded signals of primarily the core compound. A more complex coating of organic oxidation products from alpha-pinene ozonolysis showed relatively higher signals from high molecular weight products compared to those observed using conventional MS methods, indicating that some products decompose in the latter case. The use of glutaric acid as a matrix provides a powerful technique for particle surface analysis going forward without the need for sample collection and extraction, and better preserves molecular identities.

MAIV was applied to solid glutaric acid particle oxidation at the surface using the most common atmospheric oxidant, hydroxyl radicals. An especially significant result was the observation of peroxide formation at the particle surface at similar intensities to those of expected stable products. Peroxides are generally unstable and have traditionally been observed as very minor oxidation products. Their clear detection suggested that conventional analysis, which requires extraction and high energy for ionization, leads to decomposition. Peroxides have oxidative properties, thus their surface detection may have implications for health and atmospheric processes.

A second method developed in this laboratory, Easy Ambient Sonic-spray Ionization (EASI)-MS, was applied to these particles. EASI-MS has configurations that allow both bulk and surface-sensitive analysis and also uses little energy during ionization. Both configurations showed unambiguous peroxide formation along with expected stable products, indicating that much less decomposition occurs, as with MAIV. Comparison with an offline electrospray method that employs high temperatures and voltages led to peroxide decomposition. MAIV and EASI-MS are advantageous tools for particle surface analysis, especially for labile compounds.

One aspect of this research was to better understand water uptake onto particles, a process important in the atmosphere and that also forms the basis for many widely used particle concentrators. These devices increase concentrations for toxicological studies by condensing water onto particles to focus the resulting droplets, pumping away remaining gases, and subsequently removing excess water. A collaborative project with a health effects group examined the impact of water uptake in these concentrators on the particle composition. A bulk particle analysis method was available that provided the oxygen content of particles before and after the concentrator. Ambient particles with a significant fraction of ultrafine particles (equal to or less than 100 nm) containing little oxygen were not efficiently enriched, while larger diameter laboratory-generated particles with a similar average oxygen content were efficiently enriched. Recognizing changes in composition due to such particle concentration methods is important for interpreting the results of toxicology studies.

This research has led to valuable advances in surface-sensitive analysis of particles via methods that require low energy and little sample handling. Observations herein have provided fundamental insight into interfacial particle composition. The laboratory techniques used in this research have also been used to train postdoctoral fellows and undergraduate students and the impacts have been highlighted during several student outreach events at UC Irvine.
